Award.AwardTitle: SHF: Small: Physics-Based Electromigration Assessment and Validation For Reliability-Aware Design and Management

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Long-term reliability has become a significant challenge for design of integrated circuit (IC) chips used in today's computers and smart phones. Among many effects, electromigration-induced reliability has become the dominant limiting factor due to aggressive transistor scaling and increasing power density. In this project, the PI proposes to address IC reliability problems by providing more accurate electromigration models and assessment techniques at both circuit level and system level so that electromigration induced reliability and aging effects can be fully accounted, leveraged and optimized at both the design stage and run time stage to improve chip reliability and their lifetime at minimum design costs. Furthermore, through the collaborations with the industry partners, the proposed techniques are expected to impact the design and tool development community, thus increasing design productivity. This project also enables the institution to hire students from underrepresented groups, thus enhancing the diversity of science and technology workforce.

The project seeks to develop new physics-based electromigration models and full-chip assessment techniques, to perform model validation for accurate yet efficient electromigration verification at the design stage, and to enforce electromigration-aware reliability management at run time for nanometer IC chips. First, the research will develop new physics-accurate electromigration models to better predict mean time to failure for multi-branch interconnect trees, which are commonly seen in IC chips, for both void nucleation and void growth phases. Second, the project will develop electromigration models that can accommodate time-varying temperature and current densities, which reflect a more realistic chip working condition due to time-varying loads for both single wire and multi-branch interconnect trees. On top of this, the project team will develop resource-based electromigration models, which are more amenable to the system-level run-time reliability optimization and management.

Institution.Name: University of California-Riverside
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE

ProgramReference.Text: DES AUTO FOR MICRO & NANO SYST
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Title: SHF:Small: Physics-Based Electromigration Assessment and Validation For Reliability-Aware Design and Management

PI: Sheldon X.-D. Tan, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, UC Riverside

Project period6/1/2015 ? 5/31/2020

This project seeks to develop new physics-based electromigration models and full-chip assessment techniques, and to perform model validation for accurate yet efficient electromigration verification at the design stage and electromigration-aware reliability management at run time for nanometer IC chips. Following are major tasks finished:

  1. Dynamic physic-based EM models considering time-varying temperature and current densities. 
  2. Dynamic reliability management for many-core dark silicon microprocessors
  3. EM modeling and analysis for multi-branch tree-based interconnects.
  4. Physics-Based TDDB modeling and full-chip TDDB assessment for interconnects
  5. Finite difference time domain method for electromigration analysis of multi-segment interconnect tree. 
  6. Voltage-based fast electromigration immortality analysis for multi-segment copper interconnect wires
  7. Fast EM stress evolution analysis for interconnect trees using Krylov subspace Method
  8. Accelerating EM aging for fast failure detection for nanometer  ICs
  9. EM-lifetime constrained power grid optimization considering multi-segment interconnect wires
  10. Accelerating electromigration wear-out effects based on configurable sink-structured wires
  11. Postvoiding FEM analysis for electromigration failure characterization
  12. Multi-physics-based FEM analysis for post-voiding analysis of electromigration failure effects
  13. Saturation volume estimation for  multi-segment copper interconnect wires
  14. Dynamic reliability management for multi-core processor based deep reinforcement learning
  15. EM-aware power grid optimization considering new EM immortality constraints

In the following, we list the three major contributions from this award.

1. Physics-based three-phase EM models for multi-segment interconnects

In this work, we proposed a new physics-based three-phase  EM modeling for general multi-segment interconnects as show in Fig. 2.  The model consists of three phases of EM failure process: the nucleation phase, void incubation and void growth phases. The new EM model is more closely characterizing the EM failure process and the resulting wire resistance change process and it can be used for single and multi-segment interconnects. The new EM models also consists of two new fast EM immortality checking methods, one for the nucleation phase and one for the incubation phases even the wire has nucleated. As a result, it can significantly reduce the conservations of the existing Blech?s product based EM immortality check method.  [Tan et al, Book 2019]

2. Accelerating EM aging for fast failure detection for nanometer  ICs

In this work, we developed an advanced aging acceleration technique based on electromigration (EM) reliability induced failure mechanisms. The new technique can allow accelerated EM-induced aging of interconnect wires in integrated circuits (ICs) at the normal working conditions for the first time.  As a result, the new technique can allow the in-situ EM aging acceleration when the IC is working normally, which is not possible with the existing method. By combining this with the temperature based acceleration technique, the proposed reservoir-based acceleration method can reduce the lifetime of the IC from 10 years to just a few hours as shown in Fig. 1, which makes the proposed technique very attractive to practical EM failure detection and evaluation. [Sun, ASPDAC?18, Sadiqbatcha, SMACD?18, Sadiqbatcha, TCAD20]

3. EM-Lifetime Constrained Power Grid Optimization Considering Multi-Segment Interconnect Wires

 In this work, we propose a new P/G network sizing  technique based on recently proposed fast EM immortality check method for general multi-segment interconnect wires based on  an   physics-based EM assessment technique for fast time to failure  analysis as shown in Fig. 3.  We first show that the new P/G optimization problem  subjected to voltage IR drop and new EM constraints can still be formulated as a sequence of linear programming (SLP) problem. The  new optimization will ensure that all the wires will not fail if all  the constraints are satisfied. To further consider EM-induced aging  effects on power supply networks for the target lifetime and mitigate the over-conservation of the first optimization  formulation, we further propose an aging-aware P/G optimization method, which allows some short-lived wires to fail or to age and optimizes the rest of the wires considering resistance increase of  those failed wire segments. We also consider the new EM immortalities for both nucleation and incubation phases [Zhou, ASPDAC?18, Zhou, ASPDAC?20].

The PI?s team has published 25 conference papers and 19 journal papers. On the education side, several Ph.D. students received this supports from this award include Dr. Xin Huang, Dr. Kai He, Dr. Taeyoung Kim, Dr. Hangyang Zhao, Dr. Chase Cook, Dr. Zeyu Sun. All the Ph.D. students joined the US companies such as Oracle, Cadence Design System, Synopsys, Intel Corp, Google after graduation. Ph.D. student Shaoyi Peng and Han Zhou and Sheriff  Sadiqbatcha also partially supported by this award. 

In addition, several undergraduate student researchers, such as, Hsin-Yu Fan Chiang (female), Matthews Lumantas,  Karina Rowe (female, Latino),   Michael O?dea, Jonathan Clarke, Christian Campos (Latino), Ally Thach (female), Cindy Ho (female), Abraham Park were supported by the REU funds of the award. They worked on various projects related to the NSF sponsored project.

Tan, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, UC Riverside Project period6/1/2015 ? 5/31/2020 This project seeks to develop new physics-based electromigration models and full-chip assessment techniques, and to perform model validation for accurate yet efficient electromigration verification at the design stage and electromigration-aware reliability management at run time for nanometer IC chips. Following are major tasks finished: Dynamic physic-based EM models considering time-varying temperature and current densities. Dynamic reliability management for many-core dark silicon microprocessors EM modeling and analysis for multi-branch tree-based interconnects. Physics-Based TDDB modeling and full-chip TDDB assessment for interconnects Finite difference time domain method for electromigration analysis of multi-segment interconnect tree. Voltage-based fast electromigration immortality analysis for multi-segment copper interconnect wires Fast EM stress evolution analysis for interconnect trees using Krylov subspace Method Accelerating EM aging for fast failure detection for nanometer ICs EM-lifetime constrained power grid optimization considering multi-segment interconnect wires Accelerating electromigration wear-out effects based on configurable sink-structured wires Postvoiding FEM analysis for electromigration failure characterization Multi-physics-based FEM analysis for post-voiding analysis of electromigration failure effects Saturation volume estimation for multi-segment copper interconnect wires Dynamic reliability management for multi-core processor based deep reinforcement learning EM-aware power grid optimization considering new EM immortality constraints In the following, we list the three major contributions from this award. 1. Physics-based three-phase EM models for multi-segment interconnects In this work, we proposed a new physics-based three-phase EM modeling for general multi-segment interconnects as show in Fig. 2. The model consists of three phases of EM failure process: the nucleation phase, void incubation and void growth phases. The new EM model is more closely characterizing the EM failure process and the resulting wire resistance change process and it can be used for single and multi-segment interconnects. The new EM models also consists of two new fast EM immortality checking methods, one for the nucleation phase and one for the incubation phases even the wire has nucleated. As a result, it can significantly reduce the conservations of the existing Blech?s product based EM immortality check method. [Tan et al, Book 2019] 2. Accelerating EM aging for fast failure detection for nanometer ICs In this work, we developed an advanced aging acceleration technique based on electromigration (EM) reliability induced failure mechanisms. The new technique can allow accelerated EM-induced aging of interconnect wires in integrated circuits (ICs) at the normal working conditions for the first time. As a result, the new technique can allow the in-situ EM aging acceleration when the IC is working normally, which is not possible with the existing method. By combining this with the temperature based acceleration technique, the proposed reservoir-based acceleration method can reduce the lifetime of the IC from 10 years to just a few hours as shown in Fig. 1, which makes the proposed technique very attractive to practical EM failure detection and evaluation. [Sun, ASPDAC?18, Sadiqbatcha, SMACD?18, Sadiqbatcha, TCAD20] 3. EM-Lifetime Constrained Power Grid Optimization Considering Multi-Segment Interconnect Wires In this work, we propose a new P/G network sizing technique based on recently proposed fast EM immortality check method for general multi-segment interconnect wires based on an physics-based EM assessment technique for fast time to failure analysis as shown in Fig. 3. We first show that the new P/G optimization problem subjected to voltage IR drop and new EM constraints can still be formulated as a sequence of linear programming (SLP) problem. The new optimization will ensure that all the wires will not fail if all the constraints are satisfied. To further consider EM-induced aging effects on power supply networks for the target lifetime and mitigate the over-conservation of the first optimization formulation, we further propose an aging-aware P/G optimization method, which allows some short-lived wires to fail or to age and optimizes the rest of the wires considering resistance increase of those failed wire segments. We also consider the new EM immortalities for both nucleation and incubation phases [Zhou, ASPDAC?18, Zhou, ASPDAC?20]. The PI?s team has published 25 conference papers and 19 journal papers. On the education side, several Ph.D. students received this supports from this award include Dr. Xin Huang, Dr. Kai He, Dr. Taeyoung Kim, Dr. Hangyang Zhao, Dr. Chase Cook, Dr. Zeyu Sun. All the Ph.D. students joined the US companies such as Oracle, Cadence Design System, Synopsys, Intel Corp, Google after graduation. Ph.D. student Shaoyi Peng and Han Zhou and Sheriff Sadiqbatcha also partially supported by this award. In addition, several undergraduate student researchers, such as, Hsin-Yu Fan Chiang (female), Matthews Lumantas, Karina Rowe (female, Latino), Michael O?dea, Jonathan Clarke, Christian Campos (Latino), Ally Thach (female), Cindy Ho (female), Abraham Park were supported by the REU funds of the award. They worked on various projects related to the NSF sponsored project. Last Modified: 09/29/2020 Submitted by: Sheldon X Tan
